channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-5362] [mqtt-client] Message.ack() has no back-pressure and can result in unbounded memory growth
item.description:
MQTT client library () used by camel-mqtt component uses a lot of heap that is not collected by garbage collector, so there is a potential memory leak there.

Here is the client's Maven artifact:

<dependency>
 
   <groupId>org.fusesource.mqtt-client</groupId>
 
   <artifactId>mqtt-client</artifactId>
 
   <version>${mqtt-client-version}</version>
 
</dependency>
item.summary: [mqtt-client] Message.ack() has no back-pressure and can result in unbounded memory growth

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The leak is not in the Camel MQTT component. I refactored the example deployment so that the MQ broker is run on one machine and the camel routes are run in a different one and re-ran the test case. Memory usage on the JVM with the camel routes was nice and steady.

The memory usage on the JVM with the broker was much more intense, but I can't yet tell if it's a memory leak or if the default memory settings are just too small for the test case.
Pavel, please try increasing the max memory allocated to the JVM. If you think it's still a leak. Please reopen issue and move it to the AMQ issue tracker.

I aggree the potential leak is not in the Camel component itself but in the client library that the Camel component is using (fusesource's mqtt-client).

I'm using the very same client library in PerfCake's MqttSender (the client side of the performance test) and the memory problems are there as well. I'm using only 100 threads (2 connections per thread (request, response)) - so 200 connections - and sending a 1kB text message and 3G of maximum heap is not enough?
Attached MQTT client heap analysis taken from PerfCake.

Further investigation showed that the memory is occupied in a lot of org.fusesource.mqtt.client.FutureConnection->LinkedList->byte[] containing the message received in the context of subscribing. Even when the message is read it is not dropped from memory.

I just tried the following little main program which seems like it should be doing the same thing that PerfCake is doing. Note that I'm not that familiar with PerfCake. This little app does not leak memory. If you can figure out the difference between what PerfCake is doing and what this little app is doing please post and updated version so I can track down the leak. Thanks!

package example;
 
 
 
import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
 
import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicLong;
 
 
 
import static org.fusesource.hawtbuf.Buffer.utf8;
 
 
 
/**
 
 * <p>
 
 * </p>
 
 *
 
 * @author <a href="http://hiramchirino.com">Hiram Chirino</a>
 
 */
 
public class BlockingApiBenchmark {
 
 
 
 
 
    static public void main(String []args) throws Exception {
 
        MQTT mqtt = new MQTT();
 
        mqtt.setConnectAttemptsMax(0);
 
        mqtt.setReconnectAttemptsMax(0);
 
        mqtt.setHost("localhost", 1883);
 
 
 
        BlockingConnection publishConnection = mqtt.blockingConnection();
 
        publishConnection.connect();
 
 
 
        BlockingConnection subscribeConnection = mqtt.blockingConnection();
 
        subscribeConnection.connect();
 
 
 
        Topic[] topic = {new Topic(utf8("foo"), QoS.AT_LEAST_ONCE)};
 
        byte[] qoses = subscribeConnection.subscribe(topic);
 
 
 
        long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
 
        final AtomicLong iterations = new AtomicLong();
 
 
 
        Thread monitor = new Thread("monitor") {
 
            @Override
 
            public void run() {
 
                try {
 
                    while (true) {
 
                        Thread.sleep(1000);
 
                        System.out.println("Sent/Received " + iterations.get() + " messages");
 
                    }
 
                } catch (InterruptedException e) {
 
                }
 
            }
 
        };
 
        monitor.start();
 
 
 
        while (true) {
 
            if (System.currentTimeMillis() > start + TimeUnit.SECONDS.toMillis(120)) {
 
                break;
 
            }
 
            publishConnection.publish("foo", new byte[1024], QoS.AT_LEAST_ONCE, false);
 
            Message message = subscribeConnection.receive();
 
            message.ack();
 
            iterations.incrementAndGet();
 
        }
 
 
 
        monitor.interrupt();
 
        publishConnection.disconnect();
 
        subscribeConnection.disconnect();
 
        monitor.join();
 
 
 
    }
 
}
When I change the QoS to EXACTLY_ONCE the memory usage gets worse. I think there is a flow control issue /w the .ack() method.
Just fixed the back-pressure issue with commit: https://github.com/fusesource/mqtt-client/commit/e52a06e7b9290a34988e931e4649cb9397f3c74d

Thanks!
I'll try the fixed client and let you know.

PerfCake basically does the same, but it uses multiple concurrent threads (10), each repeatebly doing the publish-receive scenario. I haven't tried to use a single thread yet - I 'll to see if the memory is consumed too.

I tried the updated mqtt-client (version 1.13 from Maven Central and even the 1.14-SNAPSHOT from github) and the memory is still filled with the same stuff that the GC is unable to clean.
(I have 1G heap and the GC get crazy around 70k iterations)

So I've tracked down another flow control issue. I've noticed that a receiver can buffer grow to about 32,000 messages in memory per connection. Since that can explode your memory usage if your sending large messages I've made the following commit:

https://github.com/fusesource/mqtt-client/commit/64a0f09450e336c9478f372501993b78bd8c66a3

which should restrict the amount that gets buffered to a number of bytes which defaults to 1m per connection.

Get a fresh 1.14-SNAPSHOT if you want to test it out.

Pavel,

Have you had a chance to try out the new snapshot?
Sorry for the delay, I'm looking in right now so I'll let you know soon with the update.

So, it seems to stopp the memory growth, but now it floods the client side with exceptions after a while:

2016-05-20 08:25:13,079 ERROR [PerfCake-1-sender-thread-5]

{org.perfcake.message.generator.SenderTask}

Unable to send a message:
java.lang.IllegalStateException: The connection has remained suspended for an extended period of time so it cannot do proper keep alive processing. Did you forget to resume the connection?
at org.fusesource.mqtt.client.CallbackConnection$7$1.run(CallbackConnection.java:462) ~[mqtt-client-1.14-SNAPSHOT.jar:1.14-SNAPSHOT]
at org.fusesource.hawtdispatch.internal.TimerThread$2.run(TimerThread.java:155) ~[hawtdispatch-1.22.jar:1.22]
at org.fusesource.hawtdispatch.internal.SerialDispatchQueue.run(SerialDispatchQueue.java:100) ~[hawtdispatch-1.22.jar:1.22]
at org.fusesource.hawtdispatch.internal.pool.SimpleThread.run(SimpleThread.java:77) ~[hawtdispatch-1.22.jar:1.22]

Is there a possibility to increase or set the timeout?
I've deployed a new version which removes that IllegalStateException.
I've tried the new version and it seems fine. The memory growth is well-bounded, there is no exception and the behavior now seems stable.
Thanks for checking.. I'll cut a release soon.
Updated camel to pick up the 1.14 release
